awd_titl_txt: AF: Medium: Research in Algorithms and Complexity: Total Functions, Games, and the Brain
awd_abstract_narration:
The ubiquitous information environment around us, which has brought to the world unprecedented connectivity and availability of information, as well as newfound opportunities for individual expression, education, work, production and commerce, entertainment, and interpersonal communication, is the result of decades of research in all fields of computer science. Furthermore, our best hope for confronting the many problems this new environment has brought to humanity (privacy and fairness, to mention only two) also lies in new computer science research. Research in theoretical computer science in particular over the past half century has been instrumental in bringing the benefits of Moore's law to bear through fundamental clever algorithms and has made leaps in understanding the capabilities and limitations of computers and their software. In fact, it has articulated one of the most important problems in mathematics and all of science today: is P equal to NP? i.e, is exponential exhaustive search for a solution always avoidable?  The two investigators on this award have over the past four decades contributed much to this edifice of mathematical research in computer science, often in close collaboration. In this project, these investigators will work together in order to attack a new generation of problems: complexity questions in the fringe of the P vs. NP problem, a new genre of algorithms possessing a novel kind of robustness, research at the interface between computer science and economics related to income inequality and market efficiency, as well as research aiming at a better understanding of evolution, and of brain functions as basic as memory and as advanced as language.  The project will train PhD and Masters students and possibly undergraduates as well on these research topics. The findings of this research will be disseminated to students and researchers, both in computer science and in other disciplines, as well as to the general public, through journal and conference publications, undergraduate and graduate courses, seminars, colloquia, as well as public talks and general interest articles.

The project will work on improving our understanding of the complexity of total functions in the class TFNP and its subclasses, in view of recent research progress in that area. On complexity side, the project will: (1) investigate the complexity of an as yet unexplored, from this point of view, Tarski-like fixed-point theorem widely used in economics (2) revisit the approximability of the traveling salesperson problem and (3) explore a new kind of algorithmic notion of robustness based on dense nets of algorithms.  In algorithmic game theory, the project will: (1) explore a new variant of the price of anarchy inspired by wealth inequality, as well as the complexity of market equilibria in markets with production and economies of scale (2) research a new game theoretic solution concept based on the topology of dynamical systems (3) pursue the proof of an intriguing new complexity-theoretic conjecture about the inaccessibility of Nash equilibria.  The work will also explore certain promising directions at the interface of game theory and learning theory.  In the life sciences, the project will explore from the algorithmic point of view the problem of the true nature of mutations, and will extend recent research aiming at the computational understanding of how long-term memory, as well as syntax and language, are achieved in the human brain.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Over the past half century, the Theory of Computation -- the foundational branch of Computer Science which this project seeks to advance -- has (a) provided mathematical foundations to the various applied branches of Computer Science; (b) articulated the fundamental quests of computation, chief among them the P vs NP hypothesis -- "can exhaustive search always be avoided?"; and (c) pursued research through the "lens of computation:" -- attacking important challenges in other disciplines by dissecting the latent computational nature of scientific fields such as Economics, Quantum Physics and Thermodynamics, Biology and Evolution, etc.  The two PIs, who have participated in the past to all three kinds of pursuit -- often in close collaboration -- focused for this project in work along the lines (b) and (c).  In (b) they researched the subject of the complexity of total functions -- which they helped found three decades ago --- while in (c) they pursued research in two sciences outside Computer Science: Economics and Game Theory, whose interface with Computer Science, often called Algorithmic Game Theory (AGT) is now very well developed; and Neuroscience and Linguistics, disciplines in which there has been little such foray in the past.

The P vs NP hypothesis has been extremely successful not only articulating  one of the few most important and fundamental scientific questions in all of science, but also helped normalize the complexity landscape: The vast majority of computational problems encountered in practice are now categorized either as in P -- that is, they can be solved in polynomial time --- or as NP-complete, that is, inherrently exponential unless P = NP.  There are extremely few exceptions (leaving aside the graph isomorphism problem which seems to be inching towards P), and the vast majority of them are total function problems. These are computational problems which happen to always have a solution, and yet we know of no efficient way for finding this solution.  Examples abound: Finding the prime decomposition of a large integer, finding a collision in a hash function, finding a local minimum, and several other kinds. The study of total functions has flourished into some of the most elegant and fundamental branches of Theory with powerful connections to Cryptography and AGT, because it is in those fields that we often seek solutions (eg, private keys and equilibria) that are guaranteed to always exist.  In research supported by this project, the PIs and their PhD students opened new exciting avenues of inquiry: They introduced a new important genre of equilibrium problems based on Tarski's Fixpoint Theorem, which has since thrived as a subfield.  They extended total functions beyond NP -- heretofore the natural limit of the subject -- and as a result they ended up illuminating the subject of explicit constructions  (can we design optimal codes, or true pseudorandom number generators, or hard Boolean functions?).  They captured new realms of combinatorial mathematics through total functions, and they provided sophisticated efficient algorithms for important special cases of equilibrium or local minimum problems.

Finally, this project included an exciting computational journey into one of the most fundamental questions of Neuroscience: "How does the Brain beget the Mind?"  That is, exactly how does the activity of individual neurons and synapses result in cognition, language, intelligence? Is there a computational way to bridge this daunting conceptual gap that separates Experimental Neuroscience from Cognitive Science?  We have created a neuromorphic simplified computational model of the brain, faithful to the basic tenets of Neuroscience (brain areas, neurons, synapses, spikes, plasticity, inhibition, a few others), and able to simulate high-level cognitive phenomena. We have proved mathematical properties of this model that make it valuable as a bridge.  Most importantly, we have implemented, in this model, natural language -- arguably the most complex cognitive phenomenon of all. In particular, a parser of English (and a few other languages) implemented exclusively through neurons and synapses. (Interestingly, to implement recursion and center embedding of sentences in this parser, the PIs had to prove a new characterization of context-free languages.)  And -- more recently and far more excitingly -- the PIs implemented a language acquisition system (paper currently posted on arxiv).  That is, a simulated neuromorphic baby brain, so to speak, which, upon input of grounded sentences (presently in a toy language without transitive verbs and objects) learns how to comprehend and generate simple sentences in the language.
